text: one mealworm really I know you put two
in the tray well we can't read the minds
of birds yet but scientists say this New
Zealand Robin is pecking intensely
because it can count mealworms and it
knows it's been cheated all in the name
of researcher course which has produced
a growing body of evidence that birds
and other non-human animals can count
this experiment may look like it came
from a kid's magic kit but it's actually
a standard test first the researcher
shows a Robin that she is putting two
worms in a box then she cleverly
switches the bait by sliding in a trick
drawer loaded with only one meal work
the Robin's clearly recognize when
there's only one worm instead of the 2
they saw go into the box that's when
they search intensely there's a lot of
pecking the ability of Robins to count
is pretty well known very little
research has been done in a natural
setting like this one
these birds may be good counters because
they're thieves
the mates are always stealing each
other's food so it pays to keep track of
your Mueller
